quotes.topic_title: Career growth through “oh shit” moments
quotes.text: Moments that stretch you or moments that you feel uncomfortable in or you find yourself saying, "Oh shit. I shouldn't be here," or, "I'm under qualified to be here," those are the moments you should be seeking out.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Reframes discomfort and feeling underqualified as a deliberate signal to pursue for growth.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth through “oh shit” moments
quotes.text: Those are the moments that stretch you and give you a new foundation.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Defines why “oh shit” moments matter: they create step-change learning rather than incremental improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth through “oh shit” moments
quotes.text: So oftentimes you'll hear a career question like, "Hey, do you feel like you're growing in your role?" And that's a very ambiguous, in my opinion, way to ask this question.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Challenges a common career-growth check-in as too vague to be useful.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth through “oh shit” moments
quotes.text: A much sharper way is like, "Hey, how many, oh shit moments have you had in the last six months, year, two years, and what are they?"
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Offers a concrete framework for assessing growth by counting and naming recent stretch moments over specific time windows.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth through “oh shit” moments
quotes.text: I think if you ask yourself that question and the answer is, "It's been a really long time since I've been stretched in some meaningful way or I've felt like I'm under qualified to be there," then it may be worth digging into.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Provides a practical diagnostic: lack of recent stretch is a signal to investigate whether you need new challenges.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Lane is an incredibly deep thinker, very first principles oriented, and has built an incredible product team and culture at Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a core mental model (first-principles thinking) tied directly to building strong product teams and culture.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In part, he's done that by studying the principles and rituals of great product leaders and great product teams.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to an actionable methodology: deliberately study and adopt principles and rituals from high-performing teams.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Before that, he was Group Product Manager at YouTube, a Product Specialist at Google, and as you'll hear, he started his career as an Alaskan mountain guide and then as a manual reviewer of Google AdWords ads.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable, counterintuitive career path example that challenges conventional expectations of how product leaders are made.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I was able to slice and dice data by device types, country, user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of an experimentation capability practitioners can emulate when evaluating or building A/B testing infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern grow team stack.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams face when trying to operationalize experimentation within modern tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to wasted time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Calls out a common failure mode that practitioners can avoid by choosing fit-for-purpose experimentation infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click through metrics and instead use your north star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Encourages a metrics methodology shift from shallow engagement to business-meaningful outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and impact data point about compliance automation scale and efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: Shackleton legacy and exploration inspiration
quotes.text: It's an amazing story. Very inspiring how he put people first and brought back all of his men from this journey to the South Pole.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Highlights a people-first leadership principle and a concrete outcome (everyone returned) as a model for leading through extreme uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Shackleton legacy and exploration inspiration
quotes.text: So have taken a lot of lessons from that, but that's as close as I can come to the greatness of Ernest Shackleton.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Emphasizes learning-by-studying exemplars—extracting transferable leadership lessons from historical stories.

quotes.topic_title: Shackleton legacy and exploration inspiration
quotes.text: When I think of Shackleton, I also think of the ad that he ran for recruiting people to join his journey. Low chance of survival, incredibly hard, chance for glory if you succeed, something like that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable example of radically candid recruiting—setting expectations upfront to self-select for resilience and mission alignment.

quotes.topic_title: From Alaskan mountain guide to product
quotes.text: To be honest, I wasn't the best guide.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A candid self-assessment that models honest calibration of strengths—useful for making better career and role-fit decisions.

quotes.topic_title: From Alaskan mountain guide to product
quotes.text: There were a lot of amazing guides out there that just had ... They were almost invincible in terms of their ability to climb for 20, 30 hours.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Highlights the importance of benchmarking against true excellence and recognizing when a field demands extreme, rare traits.

quotes.topic_title: From Alaskan mountain guide to product
quotes.text: And the reason that you do that is because if someone falls in a crevasse, you want to be able to stop them or pull them out.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete example of designing for failure modes—an actionable mental model for building safety nets in teams and products.

quotes.topic_title: From Alaskan mountain guide to product
quotes.text: I really don't want to die roped to someone that I barely know and don't trust or love.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of trust as a prerequisite for high-stakes interdependence—relevant to choosing collaborators and environments.

quotes.topic_title: Mountain guiding lessons applied to product work
quotes.text: One is just preparation.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A simple but high-leverage principle: great outcomes often come from disproportionate upfront preparation.

quotes.topic_title: Mountain guiding lessons applied to product work
quotes.text: I think when you go climbing or when you guide climbing, you spend months and months preparing for usually a few days of climbing.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete model for product work: invest heavily in prep to make execution windows safer and more effective.

quotes.topic_title: Mountain guiding lessons applied to product work
quotes.text: There's also just a million checklists.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable operational methodology (checklists) to reduce errors and improve reliability.

quotes.topic_title: Mountain guiding lessons applied to product work
quotes.text: So you ensure redundancy across all your systems.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A reliability mindset practitioners can apply to software and teams: build backups and fail-safes, not single points of failure.

quotes.topic_title: Mountain guiding lessons applied to product work
quotes.text: I'll just never forget instances like that where the clarity of stay calm, assess the situation, prioritize, take action.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A memorable, stepwise decision framework for handling high-pressure moments in product and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lane studies principles and team rituals
quotes.text: And so I think anytime you find as a leader yourself repeating the same lessons, it should be a good flag to say like, oh, I should probably scale this in some way.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A practical leadership heuristic: repetition in 1:1s is a signal to codify and scale guidance via writing or systems.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lane studies principles and team rituals
quotes.text: And as you know, as soon as you write something down, you have to clarify your own thinking and so it becomes very useful for that.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A methodology for learning: writing forces precision and exposes gaps in your reasoning.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lane studies principles and team rituals
quotes.text: Most companies have career ladders with 10 or 15 levels and as soon as they hit some scale levels, there's levels between levels and I feel like I looked at the one at Google and you needed a PhD to decipher it and interpret how to operate within it.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A vivid critique of over-engineered career ladders that become hard to navigate and operationalize.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lane studies principles and team rituals
quotes.text: And so I found that I basically wanted to have a broader set of principles that transcended level.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A framework shift from level-specific ladders to enduring principles that apply across seniority.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lane studies principles and team rituals
quotes.text: And it was just a meta example of how important it is and how impactful it can be when you decide on a principle and then follow it.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: principles matter most when they’re explicitly chosen and consistently acted on.

quotes.topic_title: Coda’s role stages and compensation approach
quotes.text: When we were doing career ladders, first of all, we put it off for quite a bit of time and that was based on the advice of a lot of other leaders that said as soon as you introduce this, then the incentives flip from being company focused to being individual focused.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to delay career ladders because they can shift incentives away from company outcomes toward individual advancement.

quotes.topic_title: Coda’s role stages and compensation approach
quotes.text: We basically have five levels and we call them role stages and they go from apprentice to principal.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A simplified leveling framework (five stages) that can be applied across functions to reduce complexity and focus on growth.

quotes.topic_title: Coda’s role stages and compensation approach
quotes.text: So the bar is really, really high for principal in these levels and I think that that's appropriate. It should be aspirational that the bar is exceptionally high at the highest level of our role stages.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A clear philosophy for senior levels: make the top stage truly aspirational to preserve meaning and avoid level inflation.

quotes.topic_title: Coda’s role stages and compensation approach
quotes.text: I think most other companies, especially large companies have 10 to 15 levels. I think we've made a really conscious choice to have only five.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete contrast point that challenges the conventional multi-level ladder approach and argues for fewer levels by design.

quotes.topic_title: Coda’s role stages and compensation approach
quotes.text: And then probably the biggest difference is we have a centralized compensation committee and that's who decides compensation and so it's not the manager that drives your compensation.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A structural mechanism to reduce perverse incentives and bias by separating compensation decisions from direct managers.

quotes.topic_title: Core PM job: ambiguity to clarity
quotes.text: I think the unifying thesis is the core job of a product person in general is to turn ambiguity into clarity.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for PM work that can guide prioritization, communication, and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Core PM job: ambiguity to clarity
quotes.text: And if you think about the job of a product leader or a product manager, everything is ambiguous all the time.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Reframes ambiguity as the default state of product work, not an exception to eliminate once.

quotes.topic_title: Core PM job: ambiguity to clarity
quotes.text: So it's literally everything. And so if you're going to do the job well, you really need to get good at spotting ambiguity and turning it into clarity.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Actionable advice: treat “spotting ambiguity” as a skill to practice, not just a situation to endure.

quotes.topic_title: Core PM job: ambiguity to clarity
quotes.text: So the first one that I wrote about was systems not goals.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Introduces a principle that challenges goal-obsessed planning in favor of repeatable operating systems.

quotes.topic_title: Core PM job: ambiguity to clarity
quotes.text: But the story goes, he's done Seinfeld the show and he's got all this material from the last 15 years and he comes in one day and he says, "Look, I'm going to throw away all my material and I'm going to start fresh."
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A vivid example of resetting to a clean slate—useful for thinking about reinvention and avoiding sunk-cost inertia.

quotes.topic_title: Principle: systems not goals
quotes.text: But the goal isn't that important. What's important here is the system.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A crisp reframing that prioritizes repeatable process over outcome targets as the driver of durable performance.

quotes.topic_title: Principle: systems not goals
quotes.text: So the system that he uses is he writes for an hour every morning, doesn't write for more if he doesn't want to, and then he goes and performs at night.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable routine showing how small daily inputs compound into major creative output.

quotes.topic_title: Principle: systems not goals
quotes.text: And so the phrase I sometimes use is goals with good intentions don't work.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A memorable line that challenges the default reliance on goal-setting as a primary management tool.

quotes.topic_title: Principle: systems not goals
quotes.text: And to draw a contrast, that's just really different than a team that has some default on system for talking to customers. Every few times a week they're talking to customers for whatever reason.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: An actionable operating model for customer research that builds continuous learning rather than quarterly spikes.

quotes.topic_title: Principle: systems not goals
quotes.text: But the point is that it was default on.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A simple principle for designing rituals: make the behavior automatic via calendar/structure so it happens even when busy.

quotes.topic_title: Other principles: cathedrals not bricks
quotes.text: And the core insight here is that you want your teams to feel like they're building a cathedral and not laying bricks.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for motivating teams around mission and outcomes rather than isolated tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Other principles: cathedrals not bricks
quotes.text: And I think it's really, really easy to do when PMs are really busy on a day-to-day to just be one task after the other, really execution oriented and maybe not take the time to help the team take a broader frame, open the aperture a little bit and have a view of what the cathedral is.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode—execution busyness crowding out mission clarity—and what leaders should deliberately correct.

quotes.topic_title: Other principles: cathedrals not bricks
quotes.text: I think we've learned many times that one unexpected bit of this is that everybody needs to see a different facet of the cathedral.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that a single vision artifact won’t land for everyone; teams need multiple representations to connect.

quotes.topic_title: Other principles: cathedrals not bricks
quotes.text: So instead of just having a writeup, we may have a writeup, we may couple that with a metric, we may couple that with directional mocks and what the billboard might look like or how our homepage may change.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete, actionable method for making strategy legible by showing multiple “facets” (narrative, metrics, and visuals).

quotes.topic_title: Other principles: cathedrals not bricks
quotes.text: I think great product teams and great PM leaders tend to always orient their teams towards a broader cathedral as opposed to laying bricks.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A clear leadership principle for sustaining alignment and performance through continual orientation to the bigger mission.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop your own principles
quotes.text: Probably two things. One is reading really broadly. So I think not just reading PM style literature. Like I said, I tend to get a lot of inspiration from outside of tech.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete method for developing principles: deliberately source ideas from outside your immediate field instead of only product/PM content.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop your own principles
quotes.text: I think the other thing is insofar as you get the opportunity to mentor other people, think about what you're saying to these people. Think about, okay, this person came to me with this challenge. What was my response? Why was that my response? Am I giving that response a lot of times? Okay, maybe this is a more deeply held belief.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A repeatable self-audit framework: mine your recurring mentorship advice to surface your implicit principles and beliefs.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop your own principles
quotes.text: the insight is basically the nugget of a great story is five seconds of transformation. So if you just orient everything else around that moment of transformation, then you end up usually telling a reasonably good story.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A memorable storytelling model that can be applied to product narratives: anchor everything around a single transformation moment.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop your own principles
quotes.text: the way that you learn or the way that everyone including me learns new things is you go seek out the best at that given craft.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A practitioner learning strategy: accelerate growth by studying top performers rather than relying on generic resources.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop your own principles
quotes.text: And then obviously I think the other way to learn quickly is to throw yourself in the deep end. So insofar as you can put yourself in situations that are uncomfortable or force you to do things like tell a story or force you to come up with a clear strategy, you should always opt into those, especially early in your career.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth heuristic: choose uncomfortable, high-stakes situations to build skills faster—particularly early on.

quotes.topic_title: “Oh shit moments” as a growth metric
quotes.text: The basic thesis is that moments that stretch you or moments that you feel uncomfortable in or you find yourself saying, "Oh shit, I shouldn't be here," or, "I'm under qualified to be here," those are the moments you should be seeking out.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A clear mental model for deliberately pursuing discomfort as a signal you’re in a high-growth situation.

quotes.topic_title: “Oh shit moments” as a growth metric
quotes.text: And so I have found that they turn out to be a pretty good way to calibrate whether someone is growing in their career.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Positions “oh shit moments” as a practical growth metric you can use to evaluate career trajectory.

quotes.topic_title: “Oh shit moments” as a growth metric
quotes.text: So oftentimes you'll hear a career question like, "Hey, do you feel like you're growing in your role?" And that's a very ambiguous in my opinion way to ask this question.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Challenges a common but vague self-assessment question and sets up a sharper alternative.

quotes.topic_title: “Oh shit moments” as a growth metric
quotes.text: And a much sharper way is like, "Hey, how many, oh shit moments have you had in the last six months, year, two years, and what are they?"
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: An actionable prompt practitioners can use in 1:1s, performance reviews, or self-reflection to measure growth.

quotes.topic_title: “Oh shit moments” as a growth metric
quotes.text: And the core thesis is ... It's a bit about stoicism. But the core idea is essentially instead of running away from obstacles, you should be running toward them and that's where you experience either the most growth or the most profound moments of your life.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that encourages proactively seeking obstacles as a path to growth and meaning.

quotes.topic_title: Studying rituals: noticing and rituals dinners
quotes.text: Yeah. In general, I'm a big believer in good design and good product starts with noticing.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A simple, actionable foundation: build better products by training yourself to observe what’s actually happening before jumping to solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Studying rituals: noticing and rituals dinners
quotes.text: So I think a bunch of us that are really obsessed with rituals, we just honestly try to be great at noticing.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Positions “noticing” as a core capability and methodology for discovering effective team rituals.

quotes.topic_title: Studying rituals: noticing and rituals dinners
quotes.text: So see something happening with a customer, ask a few questions, get introduced to their team, hear about something interesting from a non-customer, ask for an intro, end up just probing and asking a lot of questions.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable research approach for uncovering rituals: observe, ask, get intros, and probe deeply across customer and non-customer networks.

quotes.topic_title: Studying rituals: noticing and rituals dinners
quotes.text: And then in many cases nowadays with Coda, we're building new rituals alongside people.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A collaborative model for ritual design: don’t just study teams—co-create practices with them in real contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Studying rituals: noticing and rituals dinners
quotes.text: We've been hosting a bunch of rituals dinners where we basically get people together for a dinner and we usually have three or four presenters at those dinners.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A specific, replicable format for knowledge-sharing and pattern-spotting across companies: small gatherings with multiple ritual “case study” presenters.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: HubSpot-style feedback flash tags
quotes.text: And as an organization, I think the core principle here is like you want to be calibrated on how much to pay attention to a bit of feedback.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Defines the underlying goal of the ritual: aligning the team on feedback severity so effort matches importance.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: HubSpot-style feedback flash tags
quotes.text: So it ranges from ... I think it's FYI, suggestion, recommendation, plea.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Introduces a simple shared taxonomy teams can adopt to label feedback by urgency and weight.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: HubSpot-style feedback flash tags
quotes.text: Okay, let's spend our time on that. Or there's a whole bunch of FYIs. I think we're fine. Let's keep going. No worries.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Shows the practical decision rule: use tags to prioritize attention and avoid overreacting to low-stakes notes.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: HubSpot-style feedback flash tags
quotes.text: Otherwise, every bit of feedback is taken the same. Which just fundamentally the impact of that is it slows everything down because now you're looking at a list of 100 pieces of feedback and you're going like, "Oh man, we got to address all this feedback." Whereas as soon as you distinguish between what's most important, it's much easier to sort through that.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Explains the counterproductive default (treating all feedback equally) and why a severity system speeds execution.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: HubSpot-style feedback flash tags
quotes.text: And making the person think through that choice I think is just a very helpful shared language.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Highlights the behavioral mechanism: forcing a tag choice improves clarity and reduces misinterpretation in discussions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The way it works is you book an appointment, you come in, you put on some very cool silky pajamas that they give you that you get to keep afterwards. You go into an MRI machine for 30 to 45 minutes, and then about a week later you get this detailed report sharing what they found in your body.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete, step-by-step description of the screening process that makes the action feel simple and repeatable.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Luckily, I had what they called an unremarkable screening, which means they didn't find anything cancerous, but they did find some issues in my back, which I'm getting checked out at a physical next month.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Illustrates that preventive screening can surface non-cancer issues worth following up on, not just the primary risk.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: According to the American Cancer Society, early cancer detection has an 80% survival rate compared to less than 20% for late stage cancer.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A stark data point quantifying the impact of early detection versus late-stage discovery.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The Ezra team has helped 13% of their customers identify potential cancer early, and 50% of them identify other clinically significant issues such as aneurysms, disc herniations, which may be what I have, or fatty liver disease.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides specific outcome rates and examples that clarify the broader diagnostic value beyond cancer.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Ezra scans for cancer and 500 other conditions in 13 organs using a full body MRI powered by AI and just launched the world's only 30-minute full body scan, which is also their most affordable.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific capability/coverage claim that frames the offering as a scalable, time-efficient methodology.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: Catalyst for scalable product reviews
quotes.text: And the core insight for most review forums or product reviews or decision forums is that they generally suffer from two problems that are hard to spot unless you've sat through hundreds of them. The first is they have standing attendees, and the second is they're normally single-threaded, meaning they're normally one topic at a time.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A crisp diagnostic framework for why many product review/decision meetings become inefficient bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: Catalyst for scalable product reviews
quotes.text: So if you've ever been in a meeting, I certainly have, where it's like, "Hey, do we have the salesperson who knows most about this or do we have the engineer who's actually implementing this here? Oh, great. They're not here? They're not a part of the standing set of attendees?" You either have to reschedule the meeting or worse, you just do the discussion without the person who's most knowledgeable, which seems crazy in retrospect.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete example of how standing attendee lists cause either delays or low-quality decisions due to missing expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: Catalyst for scalable product reviews
quotes.text: And so what happens when those things are single threaded is either the meeting is really long, so it's a three-hour review meeting once a week, and by the end everyone is about to fall asleep, or it's really short and it's really hard to get on the calendar. You're like, "Oh, can we get on the calendar in two weeks?" And the downside of the not being able to get on the calendar is that now you've just slowed down the whole velocity of the company because the throughput of your review meeting is really slow.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Connects meeting design directly to organizational throughput, highlighting the hidden cost of single-threaded reviews.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: Catalyst for scalable product reviews
quotes.text: So we built Catalyst to really solve those two problems. And so the way it works is it's essentially three one hour blocks throughout the week, and the assumption is that the whole company is free. So you can get anyone in the company for those three hours. And each topic has essentially four roles. Driver, maker, braintrust, and interested. It's a very transparent system.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A reusable operating model for scalable reviews: protected time + company-wide availability + explicit roles per topic.

quotes.topic_title: Ritual: Catalyst for scalable product reviews
quotes.text: So there may be three topics going all at the same time because they don't have overlapping attendees. And the impact of this, I think if you really watch it in progress is huge. You basically have many topics running all at the same time, so the throughput is much better and you have the right attendees every single time, and you have a clear set of drivers and roles in these meetings.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Explains the key mechanism—parallelization without attendee overlap—that increases decision throughput while improving decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Transplanting rituals and $100 voting
quotes.text: Yeah. I think it depends a lot on what your role in the company is.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A practical lens for deciding what rituals you can realistically transplant based on your scope and influence.

quotes.topic_title: Transplanting rituals and $100 voting
quotes.text: Maybe to say the extremes for a second, if you're a brand new PM to an organization, you probably shouldn't go try to remake the whole product review cycle that the head of product is really passionate about and has crafted. But you can probably take a decision template or some interesting ritual that has facilitated a team in the past and use it with your team.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Actionable advice on starting with team-level rituals instead of attempting org-wide process change without authority.

quotes.topic_title: Transplanting rituals and $100 voting
quotes.text: The ritual is essentially you can take any set of problems or solutions or themes or whatever you want to get people's input on, and you put those into a table and then people can basically vote with their dollars and usually you allocate $100.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A concrete, reusable methodology (“$100 voting”) teams can apply immediately in planning or prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Transplanting rituals and $100 voting
quotes.text: And I have found that especially in planning processes, little rituals like this are great at getting the elephant in the room out. So it's like, "Oh wow, we have a huge spread on this one particular problem. You think it's a huge problem. I don't think it's a problem at all. Let's talk about it."
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Highlights how the ritual surfaces hidden disagreement early, turning misalignment into an explicit discussion.

quotes.topic_title: Transplanting rituals and $100 voting
quotes.text: Now to go to the other side of the spectrum, we help a lot of companies that want to remake a whole process. They want to remake a review system like Catalyst or they want to remake their decision rituals. And so in that sense, we're usually talking to a head of product or director of product or VP of product and someone who tends to have a lot more agency over the way that the team works.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Clarifies that large-scale process transplantation typically requires senior sponsorship and organizational agency.

quotes.topic_title: Process stability vs iteration at Coda
quotes.text: People are always coming up with new creative ways to make their teams run better, make decisions go smoother.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Highlights a continuous-improvement mindset where teams constantly experiment with better execution and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Process stability vs iteration at Coda
quotes.text: And we're continuously adopting those, but there's definitely a backbone of the system.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Captures the operating model of combining ongoing iteration with a stable core set of rituals.

quotes.topic_title: Process stability vs iteration at Coda
quotes.text: The backbone of the system is Catalyst and tag-ups and the concept called Bullpen.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of naming and standardizing core operating rituals as the stable foundation.

quotes.topic_title: Process stability vs iteration at Coda
quotes.text: That took us launching automations and the ability to add things to calendar in order for that whole process to really work.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: Shows how process improvements often depend on enabling tooling/automation to make the workflow sustainable.

quotes.topic_title: Process stability vs iteration at Coda
quotes.text: So in the years prior to us launching that, we did it very manually.
quotes.speaker: Lane Shackleton
quotes.context: A specific example that reinforces how operational maturity can evolve from manual to automated over time.
